body_html:
I worry that even without the --rm, people unfamiliar with Docker still won't know how to resume the stopped container. I expect they'll try the docker run command again, which will create another fresh container.

Realizing that you have to use docker ps -a to get the id of the stopped container and then use docker start to resume it seems tricky with no instructions, unless I'm missing something obvious?

body:
I worry that even without the `--rm`, people unfamiliar with Docker still won't know how to resume the stopped container. I expect they'll try the `docker run` command again, which will create another fresh container.

Realizing that you have to use `docker ps -a` to get the id of the stopped container and then use `docker start` to resume it seems tricky with no instructions, unless I'm missing something obvious?
